entries.title: We're Hiring Telecommuters - Grant Street Group
entries.text:
We're a growing software company using open source software/modern Perl practices to build innovative e-payment, auction, and tax collection web applications.
We're looking for talented, motivated professionals committed to flawless work and customer service.
Email resume: 106686-CS-6734@grantstreet.hrmdirect.com

entries.title: Marpa v. Parse::RecDescent: a rematch
entries.text: Both will allow you to write grammars, but which is faster to run? Given a specific, simple language you can see that Marpa can be more than 100 times faster than Parse::RecDescent.

entries.title: How Do I Keep My New Product Out Of My Employers IP
entries.text: Are you working on a code-based business idea while still employed? Do you have a contract that say 'everything you make, even what you dream at night belongs to your employer'? JT recommends a way out. Without quiting your job.

entries.title: Being nice to colleagues with git pre-commit hooks
entries.text: The article is about test code, but this could apply to regular code as well. How many times have you added print statements or other 'debugging code' to your application? And how many times have you forgotten to remove it before committin got Git? You can avoid it using pre-commit hooks.

entries.title: Hooking MS windows messages on Wx Perl.
entries.text: Code example how to catch the MS Windows messages that are not handled by wxWidgets.

entries.title: Applying patches from rt.cpan.org tickets
entries.text: Just got easier. Using unauthenticated curl or wget.

entries.title: Carton and perl version support: miyagawa/heroku-buildpack-perl
entries.text: Building Perl and CPAN module for Heroku, now using Carton.

entries.title: Server-side security war games: Part 0
entries.text: Mike Doherty has a series of articles that can help you think on how to secure your web site. This is the link to the first article, you'll will have to browse aroung a bit to find the rest but they can be useful, even if not Perl specific. In the latest one you could learn how to log in to a web application without providing a password.

entries.title: Catalyst 5.9004x "SicilianButtercup" Release Retrospective
entries.text: If you are using Catalyst, it can be very important to see what's going on among the core developers, even if you don't currently have the time to contribute or follow the development more closely. John Napiorkowski makes it easy with his writings.

entries.title: Thanking the Open Source developers in the Catalyst Ecosystem
entries.text: Including nice Github report on the developers.

entries.title: A new Perl 6 major mode for emacs! (In Progress)
entries.text: If the only thing that stopped you from writing in Perl 6 was your editor, then you don't have more excuses. Well, assuming you use Emacs.

entries.title: Set Operations
entries.text: So Perl 6 can have this nice unicode charactes for set operations like ‚äñ for symmetric difference;

entries.title: PHP Weekly
entries.text: In case you also do PHP sometimes you might be interested in the PHP Weekly curated by Katie Eyers and  Adrian Teasdale.

entries.title: How to exit from a Perl script?
entries.text: A short article on a short statement in perl.

chapters.title: Events
chapters.header: I usually list the next 3-4 events here. The list of all the events can be found on the web site. If your Perl event is not listed there, please let me know.
